p: To further evaluate changes in the spatial patterning of population genetic structure, we used NGSadmix to conduct a maximum likelihood (ML) analysis of historic and modern population structures [ 37]. We detected a substantial increase from two to six genetic clusters for YNP T. alpinus, compared to stable overall population structure (K = 2 across both time points) within T. speciosus ( Fig 2A; S5 Table). Principal component analyses of these data also indicate less genetic similarity among modern YNP T. alpinus samples ( Fig 2B). These genome-wide estimates incorporate genotype uncertainty to provide an accurate overview of changes in genetic diversity and structure over recent timescales. Although consistent in the direction of change, the increases in YNP T. alpinus population genetic structure appear even more striking than previously detected using lower resolution data [ 33, 38]. By contrast, there was minimal structure in T. speciosus within the same ecosystem whether considering a few microsatellite loci [ 33] or thousands of SNPs ( Fig 2A).
